title: Right-To-Die Reaction Mixed
text:
Those In Need, The Boy Scouts Will Feed 
Some people say the end of life should be left up to god, but others say the terminally ill should have options. 
Despite his Jesuit studies prior to his political career, Gov. Jerry Brown said he signed the bill on Monday. 
It will take effect next year three months after the current legislative session ends. 
But when it becomes law, it won't make it easy for terminally ill patients to end their lives. 
End of life issues will be discussed by a panel of experts at a free event entitled "Letting Go & Discovery" at the Santa Barbara Public Library Oct. 7 from 5:30 to 7:00 p.m. in the Faulkner Gallery. 
For more information go to, www.vnhcsb. 
They will need two doctors to acknowledge they have only six months or less to live. 
They must be able to take the doctor-prescribed medication to end their lives without assistance. 
And they must make the request twice, 15 days apart. 
The parents of 29-year-old Brittany Maynard fought for the law. 
The California woman was dying of brain cancer when she moved to Oregon to end her life. 
California will be the fifth state to allow terminally ill patients to legally end their lives with doctor-prescribed drugs. In addition to Oregon, Montana, Vermont and Washington have similar laws. 
The drugs used in other states are sometimes expensive and in short supply. 
The law also has a sunset provision that will allow it to expire in a decade from now unless lawmakers vote to extend the legislation.
